title: The Mayan Calendar
content:
Maya Singh had catalogued exactly 89 of Ewen's past lives in her purple notebook, which she kept hidden between her mattress and box spring. Alongside the notebook were three contraband copies of Cosmo, and a collection of pressed flowers which she couldn't bring herself to throw away because they smelled like the garden behind her grandmother's house in Penang.

Wales, Maya had discovered, was essentially the opposite of Malaysia in every conceivable way. Her brother Hari had a theory that God created Wales as a test for the faithful, like Job, but instead of killing all the livestock he jumped straight to the end with the 14,000 sheep. Not only was this theory impressive for an eight year old, it was also how the family found out Hari had been letting the Mormons into the house again.

Penang had been a riot of color; of sunset orange temples, emerald jungles, sapphire seas. Bridgend was soggy gray in an acrid haze, like the word “squelch” had become a town and taken up vaping. The Welsh had almost thirty words for rain; weeks of apologetic drizzle that eroded the joy from your very soul. Malaysian rain announced itself with theatrical thunder that shook your walls, flooded your landing and finished its business in an hour, like my father using the restroom.[1]

Where Maya’s childhood had been punctuated by the call to prayer and the shriek of tropical birds, Bridgend offered only the distant bleating of damp sheep and the occasional teen revving a Vauxhall Corsa through the ASDA car park.

Her parents had moved the family when she was six, chasing her father's job at the Sony factory, you know the one behind the McDonald's off the M4? Arjan had accepted the position with the grim determination of a man who'd calculated the exchange rate and concluded his children's futures were worth a lifetime of Vitamin D deficiency. Her mother Jasleen had cried for three months straight, then abruptly stopped, announcing she would "make the best of it" with the terrifying fortitude that only a mother could summon.

"We are pioneers," she would say, usually while aggressively sweeping the already spotless floor. "Like the Ahmad family in Cardiff. They own three restaurants now. Three!"

Maya didn't feel like a pioneer. She felt like a tiger pacing the confines of her cage as strange onlookers made unintelligible noises at her, though that might have just been the Welsh accent.

Ewen was a welcome distraction and ally. And the notebook helped them both. Each entry followed Maya's proprietary system: the Mayan Calendar she called it.

Life #: Sequential numbering based on discovery, not chronological death

Name/Location/Era: Best guesses, often wildly inaccurate

Cause of Death: Surprisingly consistent theme of "wet and unpleasant"

Swear Words Learned: The real treasure

Credibility: Scale of 1-10, where 1 meant "definitely faking for attention" and 10 meant "Ewen cried for an hour"

Practical Applications: Things that might be useful if Maya ever needed to, say, escape Wales

Doodle: Optional, but often hilarious

Life #90 had broken her scale.

"Australian spy," she muttered, tapping her gel pen against her teeth. "Female. Shot in chest. Fell off something high. Partner named Camille also shot. Something about an Oracle and the world ending." She added a few extra blood spurts to her doodle of a falling stick figure, before glancing up at Ewen. He hadn't moved from his position on her bedroom floor for the past hour. He lay spread-eagle on the carpet staring at the glow-in-the-dark stars she’d stuck to her ceiling when she was seven and her parents still thought she might become an astronomer instead of what her mother now called "a concerning child."

“Right then," Maya announced, snapping the notebook shut. "We need to jog your memory."

"I don't want to remember," Ewen said flatly. "I want to forget. I want to be normal. I want to worry about normal things like whether Katie Pembridge thinks I'm fit or if Mr. Davies noticed I copied Dylan's maths homework."

"First of all, Katie Pembridge has the emotional depth of a puddle. Second, everyone copies Dylan's maths homework, including Mr. Davies probably. Why do you think our school's maths scores are such a disaster?” Maya checked to see if he had cracked a smile, but Ewen remained stony faced.

“I just thought I was getting better.” He turned to look at her. “It had been almost a year, you know.”

“I know,” Maya knelt down beside him, choosing her words carefully. “Trust me. That’s why I think this one might be important. You just remembered being a spy who got killed trying to save the world. That's properly mental, even for you. Besides,” she added, turning away, “I heard Katie tell Jen S. that she thinks you're cute.”

“Really!” Ewen sat bolt upright.

“That’s what gets you off my floor?! Why are boys so simple?” She hauled him to his feet with surprising strength for someone who had successfully avoided every PE lesson for the past two years by claiming various religious observances.[2]

"Come on. We're doing this scientifically."

"What does that mean?"

"It means," Maya said, already rummaging through her closet, "we're going to recreate the conditions of your flashback until something else resurfaces. Trauma response therapy. I read about it in Cosmo."

"I don't think Cosmo covers reincarnation-based PTSD."

"You'd be surprised. Last month they had a whole article about past-life regression affecting your current love life. Apparently, if you died of plague in the 1300s, you're more likely to be clingy in relationships. If you drowned, you're scared of commitment. And if you were beheaded, you have trust issues."[3]

"What if you die every day, hundreds of times in hundreds of ways?"

Maya considered this. "Then you probably live in Wales."

Maya's scientific method, it turned out, owed less to actual science and more to what she'd gleaned from channel surfing CSI: Miami while her parents were out of the room. Her first experiment involved firecrackers she'd convinced Dylan to steal more of, this time from his brother's“emergency stash. (“If one firework resurfaced one memory,” Maya had philosophised, “then twenty fireworks should give us twenty memories. That’s twenty thousand percent more memories, you know.” “Wow!” Dylan had exclaimed, clearly impressed.)

Ewen now found himself sitting cross-legged behind the abandoned Woolworths, where the “EVERYTHING MUST GO" signs had been up so long they had become an existential statement.

“This is ridiculous,” he muttered.

“No, it's science. Support women in STEM,” retorted Maya. She had been sure to wear her long white jacket, the closest thing she had to a lab coat.

“Why does he look like that?” Dylan asked, bewildered.

Ewen was wearing Maya’s old boots and floral sundress, bursting out of it at the shoulders like a pale Incredible Hulk. Maya had even insisted he wear her mother’s bright red lipstick. This was the first time she’d ever used makeup, so Ewen’s aesthetic could be best described as Wilson, the blood smeared volleyball from the film Castaway.[4]

“You were a female spy. We have to control all variables. Plus, I think you look good,” Maya lied. “And if there’s one thing I’ve learned from CSI:Miami, it’s that everyone looks good. Especially that David Caruso.” Maya sighed, lost in her own Caruso-fuelled thoughts. Ewen fiddled with his dress, trying to cover up his thighs. “Maybe this is why my parents ask me to stay away from you two,” Dylan said quietly.

“Right, then!” Maya snapped back to reality. “Are we ready? Dylan, let him have it!”

Ewen closed his eyes as the pair lobbed streams of lit fireworks dangerously close to him. All at once there was heat and noise. Sparks stung his exposed shoulders and chest as he squirmed to shield himself in Maya’s dress. Explosion after explosion rang in his ears until it was almost unbearable. The smoke burned hot in his nostrils and he could have almost sworn he heard manic laughter, though it was impossible to be sure amidst the chaos.

After about the fifteenth explosion, Maya realised she was in fact cackling uncontrollably. Was throwing explosives at your friends always this cathartic? She was about to ask Dylan, when she realised Ewen had been quiet for a long time. She quickly motioned for Dylan to stop throwing, and they waited with bated breath. A thick cloud of smoke hung heavy in the air, obscuring Ewen from view. The silence was deafening. Slowly, Ewen’s silhouette appeared, like a gorilla emerging from the mist in the rainforests of Central Africa. He was still sitting cross legged but with head bowed and eyes closed. Dylan and Maya glanced at each other nervously. Was it Ewen, or had the experiment worked? Were they looking at Someone Else? The boy slowly raised his head and opened his eyes, blinking as if awakening from an eternal slumber. Finally he spoke, slow and deliberate.

“Papa no likey the sauce.” Not all of Ewen’s catchphrases were winners.

“Are you kidding me!” Maya groaned, while Dylan almost concussed himself face-palming.

“Sorry guys,” Ewen said sheepishly. “It was a good idea, Maya. Really.”

“Apparently not good enough.” Maya dug into her jacket pocket.

“Wait, why are you- oh no, are those sunglasses?”

Dylan backed away. “Please tell me this isn’t a CSI:Miami moment.”

“Sometimes...” Maya continued, flipping the shades open with a snap, "..the fire works…and sometimes…”

“Oh god, she’s doing a David Caruso!”

She slid the sunglasses on with solemn flair.

“...it's just fireworks.”[5]


Maya’s second attempt was more creative. She'd recruited her younger brother Hari to jump out at Ewen from various hiding spots throughout the day, reasoning that surprise ambushes might trigger spy memories. Hari, an eight year old with the impulse control of a caffeinated squirrel and the biblical knowledge of a Renaissance Pope, took to the assignment with disturbing enthusiasm.

"They look similar from a distance,'" Hari protested later, ice pack pressed to his head where Mrs. Chen's handbag had struck a clean blow.

"Ewen looks nothing like a 60 year old Chinese woman!"

"Well, why was she wandering the streets anyway, on the day of the Sabbath? Who knows what she was up to. Ma says we have to be careful around the Chinese because ███████ ██ ███████ ██ █ ████████  ██████ ███████ ██ ███ ██ ████ █████ ██ █████████ █ ████ ██████████ ██ █ ██████ ████ ████ ██.”

"Ma says that about everyone, Hari. Last week she said it about the Welsh."

The third attempt found them at the local library; a dull, soulless, concrete husk built like an homage to 10pm on New Years Eve. Maya had compiled a stack of books about espionage, Australia, and the Rainforests of Central Africa. They had been reading in silence for close to an hour. Ewen was just starting to dose off when Maya gasped. “Did you find something?” he asked, jolting awake.

“Get this! Did you know Australia started off as a penal colony?” Maya could barely finish her sentence without bursting into giggles.

“This is hopeless,” Ewen sighed. “Let’s go home, we did our best today.”

They walked back along the high street of Bridgend, which was busier than usual for a gloomy summer Sunday. A street musician sitting on a white bedsheet outside the Boots pharmacy began to strike a series of large bronze bells as they passed, the regal cathedral melody reverberating across the street. Maya, who had been explaining the importance of biodiversity in maintaining ecosystems in the rainforests of Central Africa, suddenly realised Ewen was no longer by her side. Looking back, she saw him standing in front of the bronze bells, stopped dead in his tracks, eyes glassy in a trance-like state. A look that Maya had seen dozens of times before. Her heart began to race. The swim trunks were sliding off.

The carillon bells rung like explosions outside the grimy windows of the safehouse where Evelyn and Camille sat, poring over the maps again. They had narrowed the potential location down to a range of about 15 degrees of latitude, but it was nowhere near close enough. The world was an immense place. Camille studied the maps while Evelyn studied Camille’s face, stony with grim determination and a faint trace of worry. Her eyes drifted past Camille to the corkboard stuffed with various photographs, newspaper clippings, hand-written notes and classified memos, all surrounding the Oracle in the centre. Close to a year of painstaking searching for an answer that still eluded them. Where was the final piece? Beyond that, five storeys below them, the quiet bustle of Leuven’s streets: cars, children, students and tourists, drifting into the studio apartment, almost sacred in its banality.

“We have to think like them,” Camille murmured, half to herself. She spoke with the polished English accent in which so many French-speakers learned the language. Evelyn always thought it was charming in its overly refined way. “They are cautious, but theatrical. They will be drawn to the mountains, the wilderness.”

“That could still be anywhere above lat 55,” Eveylyn replied. “Norway, Canada, hell, even Siberia for all we know. There’s something we’re missing, something in the files. If we could just get a hold of Joffrey then maybe -”

A loud thud against the apartment door cut her off. Evelyn and Camille exchanged a startled glance before leaping into action, rushing to pack away the documents and conceal all signs of their ongoing investigation. Sheets over boxes of files, corkboard thrown into the armoire and locked. Another thud against the door, and another, as the hinges strained against the wooden frame. They were coming in. Camille ran to the kitchenette and opened the bottom drawer, pulling out a small hard drive before tossing it to Evelyn. She motioned silently for her to exit through the window. Evelyn hesitated. She couldn’t leave Camille alone, but if they lost the hard drive…

The door burst open with a crash and two masked operatives clad in black exploded into the small apartment. “Go! NOW!!” Camille yelled at Evelyn, as she grappled one of the assailants. Evelyn flung open the window and swung herself over the small iron balcony. Nothing but air between her and the narrow cobblestone street far below her. 

She reached for the drainpipe, a classic spy move that looked infinitely more elegant in films than it felt in real life. The metal groaned ominously under her weight, which Eveln couldn't help but feel was a little rude. The hard drive pressed against her ribs as she shimmied upward, her palms slick with sweat. From inside the apartment came the unmistakable sounds of Camille unleashing creative violence using the household objects at her disposal. A lamp crashed. Someone screamed. Something that sounded suspiciously like a blender whirred to life.

"Leave it to Camille to weaponise kitchen appliances," Evelyn muttered, hauling herself up another metre, like a sloth climbing the trees in the rainforests of Central Africa. The drainpipe gave an alarming creak suggesting it too was having second thoughts about this whole endeavor. She glanced down once, a mistake that made her stomach churn. The cobblestones looked particularly hard and unforgiving from this height. She had always imagined dying in a more dignified manner, maybe saving orphans from a burning building or taking a bullet meant for someone important. Not plummeting to her death because of questionable European plumbing infrastructure.

The apartment window below her legs suddenly erupted in a shower of glass as one of the operatives was hurled through it, followed closely by Camille’s triumphant French cheers (or were they slurs?) The masked man lay half-draped over the balcony in a daze, before Evelyn saw Camille’s outstretched arm reel him back inside for further punishment.

“He’ll wish he met the cobblestones instead," Evelyn muttered, then immediately regretted reminding herself of them. The roof was tantalisingly close now, just another few metres. From there, she reasoned she could probably skirt along the rooftops of the neighbouring buildings, tightly packed like in most Belgian towns, and head toward their designated emergency rendezvous point near the river crossing. Her fingers finally found the rain gutter, and she hauled herself over the edge with the grace of a particularly determined seal. The rooftops stretched before her, a maze of chimney stacks and satellite dishes. One leap to the next building, a small climb to the one after, and she should be in the clear. She checked the hard drive was still with her, and prepared herself for the sprint ahead. But before she could take her first step, something hard and unforgiving connected with the back of her skull. The world tilted sideways, stars a As consciousness faded, Evelyn's last coherent thought was that she really should have tried a Japanese toilet when she had the chance.

"Ewen? Ewen!" Maya's voice plucked him from the resurfacing, like a chameleon’s tongue reeling in a fly in the rainforests of Central Africa. He blinked, finding himself sprawled on the high street, the bronze bells still ringing their cathedral melody. A small crowd had gathered around him, their faces wearing the particular expression of concern that the Welsh reserved for witnessing someone having what was politely termed "a moment."

"I'm fine, I'm fine," he assured them, though his hands were shaking slightly. Maya took his arm gently, steering him away from the crowd who had the satisfied air of people who'd done their civic duty by standing around looking worried.

"What did you see?" she asked quietly as they walked toward the nearest bench.

"Leuven," Ewen said, his voice still shaky. "In Belgium. There was a safehouse. It was... intense. I remember the building now, Maya. I can picture the street, the layout, everything. Camille gave me a hard drive, it was crucial. She was fighting them off while I tried to escape, but someone was waiting on the roof."

Maya's eyes lit up with the particular gleam that meant she was about to suggest something that would either be brilliant or get them both arrested. "So you know where it is? The actual building?"

"I think so. It was near the Library, the one with the carillon. On a narrow street with those old Belgian buildings, the ones that look like they have eyes that judge you."

"Sounds like my kind of building," Maya said, grinning. "Ewen, this is amazing. And you said something about a hard drive?"

“It was the one thing Camille needed me to protect. And I don’t know if I did.” Ewen was quiet for a moment. "We need to go to Leuven."

"To Belgium? Are you mental? How are two ten-year-olds supposed to get to Belgium? It's not like we can just catch the bus. Well, I guess we could catch a bus. But it would be a very long bus. And then we’d probably need to take a second bus. Is that even allowed, Ewen? Are you allowed to take a bus after you’ve just taken a bus? Is that what double jeopardy is? Because if it is-”

“Maya!” Ewen gently placed his hand on her shoulder. “In the memory, we were trying to stop something called the Oracle. What if…what if it's still out there? What if the world ending is closer than we think?"

She looked at him, really looked. Under the overcast sky, she could see the weight of 90 deaths (that she knew of) pressing down on his narrow shoulders. And yet, his eyes seemed ablaze with a fire she had never seen in him before. They burned with hope. Not just of saving the world, but something deeper that he had never spoken out loud.

This  could be the key to everything. My past lives, why I can remember them, what I’m supposed to do with these memories. The answers I never got are in Leuven, I just know it. Will you help me find them?

“So where do we get this bus?” she sighed.

Ewen beamed. “I’ve got a better idea.” His voice descended into a low whisper, like the rustle of driver ants moving through the leaves of the rainforest in Central Africa[6] as he schemed excitedly, dreaming up plans and contingencies, backup plans for the backup plans, lies to tell and truths to hide. Even though he was whispering, as an omniscient third person narrator I could totally tell you what his plan was, but I don’t think I will just yet, so there. I will however recommend an excellent book for you that may answer any questions you have.[7]

All the while, they didn't notice the gentleman by the payphone watching them with unusual interest. Or the way he immediately picked up the phone and dialed a number that hadn't been used in a decade.

footnotes.content: Despite what you may have heard, my father is actually a shy pooper. He did once walk into my room proudly holding up a new book that he had bought. He said the whole world had been talking about it and he couldn’t wait to find out what all the fuss was about. I didn’t have the heart to tell him. Two days later I found his copy of Fifty Shades of Grey discarded in disgust at the back of the bookcase. We never spoke of it again.
Her personal favorite was "Festival of the Immovable Ladder," which she claimed required her to remain perfectly still for the duration of any physical activity.
